awd_titl_txt: Particle and Gamma-Ray Astrophysics with HAWC/VERITAS (Utah Group Grant)
awd_abstract_narration:
Gamma-rays are the highest energy form of electromagnetic radiation.  Observations of astrophysical gamma-rays serve as probes of physical conditions and processes in the most extreme environments throughout the Universe and can be used to test fundamental physics.  This award supports scientists at the University of Utah to carry out gamma-ray astrophysics research using two complementary ground-based observatories.  The Very Energetic Radiation Imaging Telescope Array System (VERITAS), located in southern Arizona, is designed to study high energy gamma-rays with very sensitive pointed observations.  The High-Altitude Water Cherenkov (HAWC) observatory, located on the slopes of the Sierra Negra in Mexico, is a continuously-operating array with a wide field of view that can observe two-thirds of the high energy gamma-ray sky every day.  The University of Utah group will contribute to the operation and maintenance of VERITAS and HAWC and work on analysis and interpretation of the scientific data from both observatories in conjunction with the FERMI satellite gamma-ray observatory.  Through their leadership role in the newly formed Consortium for Dark Sky Studies the group will develop interdisciplinary connections between astronomy, and earth sciences, as well as urban planning and economic development. The group will continue and expand their existing education and outreach activities through research internships designed to bring research opportunities to physics undergraduate students in small liberal arts colleges, through the organization of the yearly SNOWPAC conference series and the meeting of the four-Corners Section of the American Physical Society, and by hosting a conference on dark skies science.   

The University of Utah group will use recently developed diffuse analysis techniques and multi-wavelength analyses to study the properties of galactic binary systems LS I +61 303 and Swift J0243.6+6124 and to resolve the putative detection of galactic microquasar SS433. The group will reprocess both new and archival VERITAS observations with these analysis techniques to search for a new class of highly-extended high energy gamma-ray sources that have been suggested by recent HAWC observations. The researchers will apply the multi-wavelength analyses to joint FERMI-VERITAS-HAWC observations to substantially improve source localization and energy spectrum constraints on point and diffuse sources.  This award supports additional work on understanding the origin of high energy horizontal muons created by extensive air showers that are sensitive to high energy cosmic ray composition and origin. This award also supports first visible band optical imaging of 30 nearby stars using stellar intensity interferometry instrumentation at the VERITAS observatory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research grant supported astronomical observations of the most energetic objects in the universe - stellar mass black holes, remnants of supernova explosions, compact stars, and high energy cosmic rays- using the VERITAS and HAWC observatories. These observations provided direct evidence for the origin of high energy cosmic rays around the Cocoon  nebula (Figure 1). The left plot shows the observed gamma rays (detected by the HAWC observatory)  emanating from the Cocoon region. There are three bright sources of gamma-rays evident. Subtracting off model of the two inner point sources, there is a residual `halo' of emission in the region (right plot). Analysis demonstrates that lower energy cosmic rays are efficiently trapped by magnetic fields in the halo.  These cosmic rays become accelerated in the halo region, and when the reach higher energies they escape the halo.

This research discovered a population of high energy particles (muons) created by cosmic rays traveling horizontal paths across the atmosphere. These particles are serendipitously observed in the HAWC observatory, and they provide a limiting background for the use of HAWC as a detector of high energy astrophysical neutrinos. Figure 2 shows the observed muon flux as a function of rock traversed by the muons (in kilometers water equivalent, km.w.e). Above 8 km.w.e. there is a plateau in the intensity of detected muon events. This plateau of muon events provides a fundamental limitation for using the HAWC detector as a neutrino observatory.

This research project supported the design, construction and commissioning of a 9.8-meter diameter  "Schwarzschild-Couder Telescope" (SCT) at the FL Whipple Observatory.  The SCT provides a wide field of view and employs a state-of-the-art "high-speed silicon photomultiplier (SiPM)" camera.  The SCT was  able to detect the Crab Nebula, a known source of high energy gamma-rays, as demonstrated in the sky image in Figure 3. The detection of the Crab Nebula demonstrated the success of the 2-mirror SCT optics and the SiPM camera.  (https://attheu.utah.edu/science-technology/utah-scientists-detect-crab-nebula-using-innovative-gamma-ray-telescope/).

This grant supported work to upgrade the SCT camera with new photosensors and increase its sky field-of-view.  The Utah group led the design of the upgraded camera, including micropositioning of the camera focal plane for ensuring the gamma ray images are properly in focus (Figure 4) . The  design employs a sealed water-cooled heat exchange system to dissipate ~6 kW of power generated by the electronics. The design is being fabricated by Utah, and will be installed on the SCT telescope in Fall 2022.

This grant has supported the development of a sensitive technique to perform ultra-high angular resolution measurements of stars at blue wavelengths. The VERITAS telescopes, using the `stellar intensity interferometry (SII) technique', measured the diameters of two bright northern hemisphere  stars (Figure 5). These observations were made during near-full moon periods, when the VERITAS telescopes are not used for gamma-ray observations. The SII measurements of Beta Canis Major is shown on the left hand side, and the SII measurements of Epsilon Ori are shown on the right hand side. The upper graphs show the 'two-photon coherence' measured for different VERITAS telescope pairs (e.g. T1T2 means the correlation between VERITAS Telescopes 1 and 2). The lower graphs show the variation in photon coherence as a function of telescope separation; a fit to this data directly measures the diameter of the stars.

 The use of an array of telescope for SII has demonstrated more than an order of magnitude improvement over previous intensity interferometry measurements of stars. (https://staging.attheu.umc.utah.edu/facultystaff/gamma-ray-scientists-bring-distant-stars-into-focus/). This grant supported observations of 30+ northern hemisphere stars and binary/multiple star systems since December 2019. These observations create an northern sky survey of diameters of stars. The SII data is being condensed into public repository for access by the general public.  

This research project supported broader impacts, such as the development of a trained STEM workforce through graduate and postdoctoral student training. Faculty and students led multiple outreach activities, including hosting public star parties at the South Physics Observatory, and working with visiting summer students on research projects. We also organized the 2018 meeting of the Four Corners Section of the American Physical Society at the University of Utah. The 2-day symposium brought more than 250 faculty and students together to present the results of their research, and gain training in new diversity initiatives for underrepresented minorities in Physics and Astronomy. 

 This grant piloted a new student training experience between the University of Utah, Smithsonian Astrophysical Observatory, and Bennington College (Vermont). Utah established the internship for undergraduate Physics/astronomy students at Bennington  to spend six weeks at the VERITAS Observatory during January/February each year. Five Bennington students have participated in this internship. Students have learned how to perform telescope observations, and developed observational analysis projects.

The Consortium for Dark Sky Studies (CDSS, http://darkskystudies.org/, D. Kieda, Co-Director) hosted the 2018 international Artificial Light at Night Conference (ALAN 2018). See   http://artificiallightatnight.weebly.com/uploads/3/7/0/5/37053463/alan_2018_booklet.pdf
